page.title: 07Cornish Mine Stacks
page.content: Cornwall is well known for its mine stacks.Most of them were built in the 19th century and used until the 1890's.There are a lot of them around the Carnkie and Carn Brea area.One of the main ones is the Bassett Mine.Most of them were for steam engines.Not all of them have shafts as some were used to power stamps.Stamps were used to crush the rocks and release the tin ore.One engine still in working order is the East Pool and people on holiday can visit it.It is a beam winching engine and was made at the Holman Foundry near Camborne.Some engines had platforms on the beam which went right down the shaft and there were crevices in the shaft large enough for a man to stand in.He could ride all the way up or down the shaft.Others had large buckets on a rope to bring the rock and ore to the surface.
